comment_text: Amazing how lack of competition in Android market makes Samsung to do things like this. 1300$ phone and they cut 0.5$ feature that already has R&D paid. Meanwhile they spend a lot on developing bloatware apps. We need LG and HTC back on the market. And about removing features… i have a defibrillator at work because it’s a busy space. In the last 3 years as far as i know, it wasn’t used by no one. However when somebody will need that, we know it’s there. Taking a photo with the S-Pen it’s probably something you do only at Christmas family gathering but that 1 minute in a year it’s important. Well done Samsung.

comment_text: Maybe this is a skip year for Samsung. They tried to pull these anti-consumer tactics before, with the Galaxy S6 when they tried removing the microSD card slot. You really hit the nail on the head with this critique, the entire point of the Ultra series is that it's the no-compromise phone. It _should_ have a bunch of features that most people don't use, because the few people who do use those features absolutely love them.

author: @tpg81

comment_text: I received my S23 Ultra and my first impressions after unboxing were how good the phone felt and looked. I was impressed. But this early delight soon faded as the battery life was so bad. I could not get through a day. The device needed a recharge in the late afternoon to get through to the end of my day. After 6 days of trying to fix this, I decided to return the device and stick with my iPhone 16. The hostility I encountered from Samsung was off the scale. I was told I had to agree to a 20% restocking charge before I could get return labels. I rejected this and now I am looking to dispose of the phone myself. My experience was terrible with Samsung. I will never deal with them in any way again. So I can't recommend this phone or Samsung as a company, and all I can do is warn others by relating my experience to you.
author: @kenozz13

comment_text: Having a Bluetooth s pen kept me extremely loyal to Samsung's top phone each year. That was the only real distinguishing feature from any other phone. I don't even use the s pen that often, but I want to have it there for when I do need it to remotely take a family picture or whatever. Now that Samsung got rid of the Bluetooth tech in the pen, I have no reason to stick with Samsung anymore. Might as well get a pixel or any other phone.
